For 50% of the MSS to have this information probably means that the tradition is ancient; and of course, I have demonstrated, to my own satisfaction at least, that \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* goes back at least to the 3\+sup rd\+sup* century. If this information is correct, then Luke was â€˜publishedâ€™ in 45/46 AD. The same sources have Matthew published seven years earlier (38/39) and Mark five years earlier (40/41), while John was â€˜publishedâ€™ thirty-two years after the ascension, or 61/62 AD. Not only were the authors eyewitnesses of the events, but many others were still alive when the Gospels appeared. They could attest to the veracity of the accounts, but could also be the source of textual variants, adding tidbits here and there, or â€˜correctingâ€™ something that they remembered differently.\f*\sup ,\sup*\f + \fr 24:53 \ft The citation of \+bd f\+bd*\+sup 35\+sup* is based on the following fifty-one MSSâ€”18, 35, 128, 201, 204, 246, 402, 479, 510, 547, 553, 586, 691, 757, 769, 781, 789, 824, 867, 897, 928, 1072, 1111, 1117, 1147, 1328, 1339, 1384, 1435, 1461, 1493, 1496, 1503, 1548, 1551, 1621, 1637, 1652, 1667, 1694, 1713, 2122, 2253, 2352, 2367, 2382, 2466, 2503, 2554 , 2765 and I.2110, all of which I collated myself.
